article.description: Seimone Augustus scored 15  of her 22 points in the second half to lift No. 5 LSU over No. 21 Arkansas, 78-72, and advance to the semifinal of the Southeastern Conference Tournament.
article.headline: Augustus' 15 second-half points power Lady Tigers
article.linkText: LSU escapes Arkansas, gains spot in SEC semifinals
article.story:
NORTH LITTLE ROCK, Ark. (AP) -- Seimone Augustus can quit answering questions about her freshman status, according to LSU coach Sue Gunter.

She never played like one anyway.

Augustus had 22 points, including two free throws with 19.4 seconds remaining in LSU's 78-72 victory Friday over Arkansas (No. 21 ESPN/USA Today, No. 23 AP) in the Southeastern Conference tournament.

"Augustus for them took over the ball game,'' Arkansas coach
Gary Blair said. "There are not too many freshmen in the country
who can take over a game of this magnitude.''

LSU (No. 5 ESPN/USA Today, No. 6 AP) advanced to play the winner of the late game between Georgia and Vanderbilt. The semifinals are Saturday.

Augustus, who leads LSU (25-3) with 15 points per game, scored 15 in the second half as LSU staved off an equally heroic effort from Shameka Christon.

The Arkansas junior scored a season-high 33 points and had 11
rebounds. Christon had 23 points in the second half, including 10
during a 15-6 run where Arkansas (21-10) tied the game at 60-60 with 8:04 remaining.

"I don't know I've ever seen a player more capable of taking
over a game when she decides to,'' Gunter said.

Arkansas had four opportunities to tie or take the lead with LSU
leading the quarterfinal game 74-72. On the last, Dana Cherry
missed the front end of a one-and-one with 22.2 seconds remaining.

One of the shots was an open 3-pointer for India Lewis after Doneeka Hodges fell down.

"I wanted to cry. If you give her open looks she's going to make it count,'' Gunter said.

Lewis, who was just 1-of-6 on 3-pointers in the tournament,
missed and Augustus' free throws gave LSU an 76-72 lead. On the
next possession, Cherry missed a running 10-footer with Augustus in
her face and Ke-Ke Tardy's free throws sealed the game with 10
seconds remaining.

LSU had four starters in double figures, including Temeka
Johnson with 15 points, while Hodges and Aiysha Smith had 11
points. Hodges added seven rebounds and seven assists. Gunter said
the Lady Tigers' balanced scoring attack hurt Arkansas' ability to
focus on defense.

"It really makes it hard for someone to double up,'' Gunter
said.

Arkansas spent much of the game slicing away at LSU leads, eight
and nine points in the first half and then a 10-point lead early in
the second half.

"It wears on you a little bit, but we never felt down,'' said Lewis, who finished with 11 points. "We felt like we were right in there, just always a shot away. We didn't feel out of it.''

The Lady Tigers led 46-36 with about 16:30 left in the game, but
Arkansas trimmed that to 48-45. LSU followed with a 6-0 run sparked
by two jumpers from Augustus.

	   However, Christon responded with 10 points in the 15-6 run to
tie the game with 8:04 remaining. Then Arkansas took a 70-69 lead
with 3:27 remaining on a 17-foot jumper by Lewis.

Johnson, who had four assists and four steals, put LSU back in front the next time down the floor with a jumper from the free-throw line and the Lady Tigers closed the game with a 9-2 run.

"I think the people who were here tonight saw a great game, period,'' Gunter said. "I am happy our kids could dig in their heels.''

Cherry finished with 16 points and seven rebounds for Arkansas.
